Waxy

I was dying to put Richard Clark out there in the old Pig Pen. It's a sure fire "win" for anyone who doesn't like the Bush Administration. Try as they might to assault his character or deny his assertions, they pretty much came up empty handed.
 
 I have obvious leanings on this, but in all the coverage I was able to see, I found Clark nothing but confident and convincing. I have no doubt this man is telling the truth, and I think the Bush camp knows it.
 
 Rice struck out at the hearings. That was a tough one, she either had to go on and admit they screwed up, or dodge the questions and just have the press assume they screwed up. In the end, I think they made the right choice, but it certainly didn't help their cause.
 
 That said, the Bush camp has done a remarkable job of spinning this or keeping it quiet. I thought it would be a HUGE story, but for the most part, the press seems to have moved on already. Some hijinks in an office will keep them busy for years, actually admitting you had prior knowledge of terrorist activity and not taking it seriously gets old in a week. That one I'll never understand.
 
 Waxy
jskufan

I think Condoleeza was in a lose/lose scenario. Either make the Bush administration look bad (admit they should have done more), which probably doesn't help her political career or admit they did the best they could (nothing) with their intelligence, which doesn't make any of the current administration look good. As for the fallout of Clark's accusations, I don't know that he isn't telling people what they already knew: our government underestimated the resolve and capabilities of Osama Bin Ladin and Al Queda. I think this would get more press if we weren't involved in that great black hole they call Iraq. If you want to criticize this administration, you have to pick your priorities, there's only some much time in the day! ;)
jim's trucking

Richard Clarke is a political liar, trying to sell his book and promote the Democratic cause (despite the fact that he's registered as a Republican).
 
 Richard Ben-Veniste is playing partisan politics in an effort to overlook the main reasons for our failure to prevent the attacks that these politicians are now being paid to look into. Our government had been asleep at the wheel regarding terrorism since the first bombing at the World Trade Center.
 
 A poor track record and poor preparation against terrorism are just two parts of a mess that Bush inherited from Clinton.
 
 What we need to do is start fixing the problems.
 
 As I type, one of the problems being exposed is the wall created between the CIA and the FBI. That wall was established by a memo written by an official in the Clinton administration (I think in 1995). The writer of the memo is now sitting on the 9-11 commission. Do you think she should resign and testify?
Waxy

Richard Clarke is a political liar, trying to sell his book and promote the Democratic cause (despite the fact that he's registered as a Republican).

 
 That's been the official Rep. party line, only problem is, they can't prove it, or even make a flimsy case to that effect. So far, he's only been proven correct.
 
 Can you point out where he has lied?
 
 Waxy
Ghost

I don't necessarily know if he's a pocket democrat or in favor of Kerry or anything like that. I think he's motivated by revenge towards the Bush admin.
 
 Waxy, it's been reported that he has said entirely different things behind closed doors with the commission and out in public and in his book. One of the commissioners said he had a 'credibility problem.'
 
 In memos, he's quoted as saying first that Bush was wonderful against terrorism before 9/11, increasing US abilities to combat them fivefold. His letter of resignation speaks in glowing terms about Bush's leadership and his abilities. Then he writes a book entirely contradicting all of this. He said originally that Clinton was terrible in dealing with terrorism, now he says he was wonderful. His stories are different, and they contradict each other.
Waxy

I haven't seen those contradictions, but admittedly, I haven't read his book, I haven't been able to get as much info on the subject as I would like, and of course, I don't have access to what goes on behind closed doors. 
 
 In the couple of cases I have seen where they thought they had him caught in a lie or contradiction, he had calm, rational, and to me anyway, very believable explanations for the miscrepancies. I haven't seen a single case where they have been able to nail him or even damage his credibility (try as they might, I even saw that old yahoo on Fox suggest it was a racially motivated attack on Rice emoticon_rolleyes ). 
 
 Rose colored glasses perhaps, but I do like to think of myself as being neutral and objective for the most part, I'm simply an interested observer of American politics.
 
 Waxy
Broker

They have him on tape contradicting himself when he was working for the administration. 
 
 You lie to make your administration look good? That or you're lying now. Either way you have a credibility problem.

 Who was the yahoo on Fox? I heard some idiot claim that it was a racial issue between him and Rice, but I think that's bull.
 
 I'm not saying ignore Clark out of hand, but do look at the facts...he does have proven contradictions, and he does have a financial interest in being controversial and putting out anti-Bush material.
jskufan

We can debate the details of Richard Clarks book all day but the fact is, we linked Al Queda to the first World Trade Center bombings, the bombing of the USS Cole, the bombing of the American Embassies, and the failed Millenium attack. How many warnings does an administration need before it takes a terrorist seriously? Blame Clinton if you like, heck blame George Sr. if you want to go back a little farther. Knowing what we did about that terrorist organization, it should have been given a lot more attention by this administration in the months before 9/11. Blame the FBI, CIA, and everyone else in Washington, just quit giving this administration a free ride. 
 
 http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/binladen/bombings/
Ghost

In retrospect, EVERYONE should have paid more attention to bin Laden and the possibility of a terrorist attack on American soil. NOBODY really expected something on the scale of 9/11, either in this administration, or Clinton's, or Bush Sr's.
 
 What matters now is that 9/11 did happen, now we need to decide how we as a nation move on. I think that Kerry will go to the UN and avoid warfare at nearly any cost...I think Bush is prepared to go to war with or without international support to preemptively attack terrorists...I agree with Bush. We've sat back long enough, and look what happened to us. We're in a world filled with people out to spill our blood. I say it's time for war.
jskufan

We've sat back long enough, and look what happened to us. We're in a world filled with people out to spill our blood. I say it's time for war.

 
 I agree with the first part of your post, EVERYONE was suprised by 9/11. It's understandable that we as civilians got caught, it's embarrassing that our intelligence communities were that easy to defeat.
 
 I strongly dissagree with the second part. As an American citizen, and a financial supporter of our military machine, I want us to avoid going to war at all costs. I've never correlated this mess in Iraq with fighting Al Queda, that was a concept that surfaced when the weapons of mass destruction never materialized.
Waxy

Who was the yahoo on Fox? I heard some idiot claim that it was a racial issue between him and Rice, but I think that's bull. 

 
 My mistake, it was Robert Novak on Crossfire.

hvozdany

Who was the yahoo on Fox? I heard some idiot claim that it was a racial issue between him and Rice, but I think that's bull.
 

 
 
 Rob Novak...one of the conservatives on CNN"s Crossfire, among other things...to be fair, that show is so politically biased on both sides, that it seems a lot of people end up saying silly things. Still, that did seem almost a new low...I to have to give the Republicans credit in a way, though...I have heard that a few times that some Republicans think that the reason some Democrats have a problem with what Rice says is because she is African American. For the Republican party, who has had some problems with racism to put it mildly, to accuse the Democrats of being racist because the Bush administration has found the two or three African Americans in this country who are Republicans and put them in the cabinet, is either genius or really crazy.

 ...
 Clark nothing but confident and convincing. I have no doubt this man is telling the truth, and I think the Bush camp knows it.
 ...
 I thought it would be a HUGE story, but for the most part, the press seems to have moved on already.  I agree very much with you. I thought that it would be much bigger than it has been is some ways. Though it may be that there is just a lot of other things going on lately with Iraq, and the commission (the PDB, for example). And, I think that he may still be mentioned and brought into the spotlight continually as the election nears. I still do think that he has been the most brought more atttention than any other single person...though you do seem to be right, people grow tired of such stories quicily, unfortunately...
 
 I also agree that nothing, as far as I have seen, has really been discredited...the only attacks have been that 1) he said different things, put a positive spin on things WHILE HE WAS WORKING FOR THE ADMINSTRATION. It still suprises me that people seem to be so shocked that a person who works for the adminstration doesn't always tell the complete truth, and puts a positive spin on things. and 2) that he is only doing this to make money, which is , obviously purely speculative and a very weak argument if you can't refute anything that he has said. Even if he is doing this only for money, as far as I have seen, nothing that he has said has been shown not to be true...really, then, I think, why he wrote the book isn't even very important.
Ghost

I agree with the first part of your post, EVERYONE was suprised by 9/11. It's understandable that we as civilians got caught, it's embarrassing that our intelligence communities were that easy to defeat.
 
 I strongly dissagree with the second part. As an American citizen, and a financial supporter of our military machine, I want us to avoid going to war at all costs. I've never correlated this mess in Iraq with fighting Al Queda, that was a concept that surfaced when the weapons of mass destruction never materialized.

 
 I don't think it's that our intelligence communities were easy to defeat. We have to understand that there is so much going on behind the scenes that our opinions are entirely unfounded. What I do know is that for our intelligence groups to entirely protect the US from terrorist acts, they need to be 100% accurate 100% of the time...for the terrorists to pull off an attack, they need to get lucky just once.
 
 I can understand your reluctance to going to Iraq and I don't blame you for it. It is a diffcult situation, and it's no problem that me and you disagree on it. I think both of us have valid points in the end. I do have a question, though: should we fight al-Qaeda? Should we have gone to Afghanistan? To what extent should we get involved to fight terrorism?
jskufan

 Ghost, Ill put my cards on the table concerning Iraq and terrorism.
 
 I've never felt we were justified with invading Iraq. I'm not speaking from the humanitarian standpoint, I'm speaking from the military strategic standpoint. I feel the threat they posed to the US was vastly overestimated and oversold to the American citizens. It has cost, and will continue to cost our country tremendously, both financially and through loss of lives. It's obvious now how little homework this administration did on the subject of "post war planning". Day after day, month after month, the dollar signs keep clicking away, and the casualties keep rising. Did you ever stop and think that the rest of the world may have been right??
Ghost

I don't think anyone could have predicted accurately what has happened...there's a saying that 'no plan ever survives initial contact with the enemy.' I agree, we didn't do as much 'homework' as could have been done, but that's hindsight. 
 
 What I was asking about was your position on fighting al-Qaeda, not the Iraq War.
jskufan

I don't think anyone could have predicted accurately what has happened...there's a saying that 'no plan ever survives initial contact with the enemy.' I agree, we didn't do as much 'homework' as could have been done, but that's hindsight. 
 
 What I was asking about was your position on fighting al-Qaeda, not the Iraq War.

 
 At the risk of supplying an oversimplified answer, let me say I'm in favor of "fighting" Al Queda. Going into Afghanistan after 9/11 was probably appropriate, but I think people are putting to much emphasis in capturing Osama Bin Laden. We captured Saddam Hussein months ago and it didn't make our struggle in Iraq any easier. Don't get me wrong, I think he's a valuable prisoner, but I don't think capturing him tomorrow would necessarilly end terrorism. We need to overhaul our intelligence community so individual agencies can share information among themselves. Finally, we need to be very careful who we tie our wagons to, many of our enemies today were people and nations we courted years ago. We were perfectly happy to train Osama Bin Ladin when he was fighting the Russians, now we're trying to fight a monster we helped create.
faeden

It seems to me that the war in Iraq does serve at least one importiant goal. If you attack the US, you (or others who sympathize with you) will face the consequences - and no one can predict what our reaction will be.
 
 Terrorists (IMO) will think twice next time, as will those who support them.

 In the beginning of the Iraq war, the "shock and awe" phase, the United States illustrated what every other nation already knew, we have the strongest military force in the world. We outspend every other nation by tens of billions of dollars so that's no suprise. As for scaring terrorists, remember these people are already willing to die for their cause. Those planes that attacked the Twin Towers and Pentagon also killed the terrorists that hijacked them. I'm not sure you can "scare" this type of person.

 Well Jsku your hind site, along with all the rest of ours, is 20/20. It is very easy to sit at your computer and type "more should have been done." The information that was availible to Clinton and to Bush suggested that these guys wanted to attack in America. Big deal they had been WANTING to attack in America for many years. The truth is, no one believed they could pull off a plan as complicated as 9/11.
 
 Lets suppose for a moment that Bush knew what was going on. He calls the FAA and grounds all air planes in American territory and diverts the plan. Nothing happens. Except of coarse all the liberals are screaming that Bush shut down a billion dollar industry, cost America untold amounts of money, and is a lousy president that shouldn't be re-elected because he lied and nothing happened. Do you honestly believe that any president that knew of a pending attack would be caught infront of school kids during the attack? 
 
 If you are looking for someone to blame for 9/11, blame Osama. Should Clinton have started the wheels turning after the first tradecenter bombing? If he had activated Home land security then would it have diverted 9/11? Who knows and who cares. It wasn't done. All we can do is try to avert future attacks from this day on.
 
 As far as Dick Clarke goes, you leftys keep throwing stuff at the wall. Eventually you may find something that sticks.

 Haulingboat, if you don't take anything else from this post, I would appreciate you contemplating one key point. Questioning the competence of our administration on the pre and post 9/11 handling doesn't make someone a liberal or as you say "lefty". I'm probably as conservative as they come. Secondly, it's not my job to protect the American people from terrorism. That responsibility belongs to the giant bureaucracy in Washington that milks us all out of 1/3 of our annual income. My opinion is that we can never stop terrorism altogether, any more than we can stop violent crime in our own nation. We knew years ago that locking the cockpit doors could prevent would-be hi jackers and crazy people from getting control of an airplane. I could care less about Dick Clark's book, I understand there are always two sides to every story. However, some Republicans are just as guilty of dismissing any negative information about this administration just as a political reflex. That said, welcome to this forum!! :)

 I see your point and perhaps things could have been handled differently. So what. Should have, could have , would have does not change the past. Maybe Bush could have handled things differently, maybe Clinton too. Hell maybe Reagan should have blow up Osama after he finished with the Ruskies. It does not change the past that we must live with. Bush is quit the spender and by no means a perfect candidate. However he has recognized the challenge and inacted policy to confront it. Which is more than his Daddy or Clinton accomplished.
 
 P.S. It is your job to stop terrorism. That job falls on the shoulders of all of us. We must elect the best person to help us defend ourselves. We cannot rely on the nanny government to do the job alone or for us. Your lefty views are shining thru again.

 Haulingboat, if you could go back and read through the archived Pig Pen and OTL you would see a consistency in my posts. I'll refresh your memory since that isn't possible. I declare myself an independent, I have opposed the Iraq invasion since the beginning, (but probably not for the reasons you think), I'm actually not union, I have a bachelor of science degree in business administration with a concentration in accounting from KU and I have run the construction equipment division of our company for the last 21 years. I oppose big government, higher taxes, and wasteful government spending. I honestly feel I'm much more conservative than liberal. I was being sarcastic when I said it wasn't my job to fight terrorism, I was being critical of the many agencies who actually exist to do that job and didn't. Lastly, I'm not criticizing Republicans or Democrats in general. I didn't say I would never vote for a Republican for president, I just said I wasn't happy with the current one. If you want to know where I stand on any issue, just ask me, but please don't label me a liberal after reading 2 posts! ;)
Maineiac

I too found Clark to be quite credible.I listened to his testimony in front of the commission,and found him to be well versed on the subject matter.He made some very convincing statements to the commission on his ideas of how things were being mishandled.It seemed to me that he had very little access to Bush while he was part of the Bush addmin.I was totally surprised to find that he was constantly dealing with deputies,and not principals.His apology to the American people ,I thought,was a very noble thing to do.He certainally Give me the impression that he was telling the truth. I suppose it would be difficult to address Bush personally,as he was on vacation prior to 9-11 :)

In the beginning of the Iraq war, the "shock and awe" phase, the United States illustrated what every other nation already knew, we have the strongest military force in the world. We outspend every other nation by tens of billions of dollars so that's no suprise.

 
 Yes, everyone knew we had the strongest military on earth. That wasn't the issue. The issue was that the US has the strongest, best-equipped, and best trained fighting force in the world...and it will use it. Up until Iraq, maybe kinda Afghanistan, nobody thought that the US would realistically enter a large-scale war, because Slick Willy Clinton had given us a reputation of being a paper tiger.
jskufan

If everyone was "amazed" in the early days of the invasion, I'm sure they're all just as "suprised" to see such intense fighting still going on one year later.
